Fields.DialogueText: Hi, Delhi. What are you carving there?
Like it? I am making two elephant tusks out of marble.
Neat. If I recall, your emblem has an elephant on it.
Exactly. That's what gave me the inspiration.
Although... aren't Asian elephants the smaller kind?
I'm actually basing the design off the African elephant. We stopped at Port Elizabeth a while back, and I was struck by how their symbol matched my own.
That's pretty cool. It won't be quite the same as ivory, though.
I know, but given all the trouble they've been having, I thought I would use a different material.

Fields.MenuText: What do you admire most in the elephant?
What do you plan to use the "tusks" for?
Hopefully we can find a way to live in harmony with nature as well as with each other.

Fields.DialogueText: Many things. They value the lives of their companions in much the same way humans do. They've even been known to hold funerals.
Decoration, of course. A medium like this simply isn't proper for utilitarian purposes.
Such is the challenge of fate in life. But one day, as long as we continue journeying forward, we will find what we are all looking for in our hearts.
It looks like they're about finished.
They are. Actually, would you like one?
Really? Usually an elephant has two tusks.
Yes. When I was making them, I was thinking we could have one apiece.
Thanks. This is a great present.
It's also a present for me as well. I can always think of you when I look at my own.
We make quite a pair, don't we?
That's what makes us so strong in combat– and here we go again. Let's do it!
@BATTLE
Brrr! It sure is windy today.
Come, it's not so bad.
Easy for you to say! I just saw a spare anchor go flying by like a piece of seaweed!
Don't worry, that was just a brief gale. It's fine as long as you keep a hold of things.
You almost sound like you enjoy this weather.
It has a nice feel to it. Reminds me of South Africa and Wellington. Doesn't it give you a sense of freedom?
That's an interesting way of looking at it, especially since your dupatta is making a break for it.
What?! Come back here!
Not as funny anymore, is it?
Don't just stand there! Help me catch it before it blows overboard!

Fields.MenuText: Don't bother. It's already too late. You can always make a new one.
All right, I'll see if I can grab it for you.
What? No confidence in your talents as a huntress?

Fields.DialogueText: You're probably right. But I can just start over from scratch. No biggie.
Thank you, Captain! That was very nice of you.
You're right. This challenge is a piece of cake for me!
All right, maybe the weather is a little rough.
Well, maybe we're both right in a way. The wind is dangerous, but it has its own charm as well.
Just like the Morganas over there.
Yeah, just like them. Wait, what do you mean by "over there?"
See?
Hopefully the wind will hamper them as well. If not, we'll still make it through.
@BATTLE
Hello, Delhi. What are you doing?
What does it look like I'm doing?
Well, I don't know. How would I?
That won't do. Put a little more rhythm into it!
I mean, How would I know?
Life is a mystery. We must guess to get anything done.
But is it better to be sure first?
Who are we to know? Fate eludes us all.
Ha, ha! All right, to be serious, what is all this?
I was trying to develop my own form of Ghana.
Like the country?
No, it's a special form of music performed on Malta. To the faint music of guitar, people present their arguments in a lyrical format.

Fields.MenuText: Then which is more important: the music or the lyrics?
This actually sounds like a lot of fun.
We'll need a third person to play the guitar.

Fields.DialogueText: You can't have one without the other. Each component brings something essential to the whole.
I know. It's a little tricky at first, but it's great once you get going.
This is just the practice stage. I'm thinking of getting more people involved once I've got the hang of it.
Hey, want to give it another go?
Sure! Do you think we can defeat the Morganas?
Certainly! We'll fight again and– not again...
Remember to pay attention to the tone.
And you remember to pay attention for enemies!
@BATTLE
Hmm... Where to put them...?
What are you doing, Del?
I'm thinking about rearranging my quarters.
Why? They look all right at the moment.
I know, but I wanted to apply the art of feng shui to it.
That's the practice where you try to organize things in the correct way, right?
Yes, I learned about it when I was in Hong Kong. I admired the desire to find the best way to live in harmony with one's surroundings.
I see. So how do you plan to change things around?
That's the issue. I can't figure out the best approach. Do you think you could give me a hand?

Fields.MenuText: There are a lot of different ways that could be seen as the "right" way. Don't get too caught up on the specifics.
Perhaps you could try meditating for a bit? That might get you into the right mindset.
Maybe go for something with a sort of natural, flowing feel to it.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. Everyone has their own interpretation of what works best. I just need to find one that works well for me.
Good idea. Here I go!
That's perfect! Something that symbolizes the transient nature of life...
... Well, what do you think?
It looks great! You did a wonderful job with the remodeling.
Thank you. Perhaps I can do the same for you someday.
That would be nice. On the other hand, with the Morganas always out there, we don't have much time to spare.
You're right about that. Hopefully this next battle doesn't shake up the feng shui too much.
@BATTLE
Reading The Mahābhārata again?
You remembered the name! But actually, I was reading another Indian classic - the Ramayana.
What's that one about?
It focuses on the reincarnation of a god saving his love from a demon.
Ah, the old tradition of a noble quest. Those are always a pleasure to explore.
Yes, though it didn't quite work out in the end...
What do you mean?
After the rescue, there were rumors that his wife, Sita, had been unfaithful in her captivity. And he did not believe her until she proved it in a trial by fire, literally.
Wait... by literally you really mean...?
Literally, she burnt herself on a pyre, as one of the first instances of sati. And that still wasn't enough to satisfy people.
And I can tell you don't like that ending.
It's frustrating that she had to die before anyone truly understood or cared about her.

Fields.MenuText: I'll always believe in you. After all, whenever you speak, it is from the heart.
Well, the practice has been outlawed now, hasn't it?
A lot of fairy tales end badly. That's sometimes how the world works.

Fields.DialogueText: You will?
It has been, but people still practice it. I know that a lot of things are open to interpretation and that it's tradition, but surely people will realize that this is wrong, right?
I know. Even a happy ending may not stay happy if you go far enough. Perhaps a tragedy awaits us as well, but I will continue to believe in a bright tomorrow.
I feel like having a smoke.
You dislike sati, but you like to light things up nevertheless, don't you?
Don't worry. I'll never let you catch on fire like that. No matter how many Morganas try to say otherwise!
@BATTLE
Of course.
Thank you. I try to be sincere in all I do.
Of course you will. That's who you are.
That's a nice sketch you're making there, Delhi. It has a very natural feel to it.
That's only natural, since the subject is wild.
Wild is right. That is one fierce leopard.
And cuddly, too.
I guess. You did a good job at portraying it accurately, though. It looks really cool.
Thanks. I remember sighting a Zanzibar leopard when we had shore leave over there.
I like how it looks so bold, standing alone in the sunset.
Yes... and the remainder may very well be alone by now.
What do you mean?
I've been hearing that there have been more conflicts between villagers and leopards as farmlands expanded.
Ah... And I can guess that there's been an upsurge in leopard attacks, right?
Exactly. It's not their fault, though. The leopards are just trying to survive, but they are made out to be demons. I don't know if anything will be done for them in time.

Fields.MenuText: The farmers are only trying to make ends meet.
If the leopards cannot speak in their defense, someone else will have to do so.
It would be a shame if they all died.

Fields.DialogueText: I know that, and I pray for them as well. I just hope that we can find a way to all live in harmony on this planet.
You're right. If not me, then someone else that the people there will listen to.
Indeed. We all have a place in life, if we take the time to understand and care about each other.
I wonder if the Morganas have a similar tale.
Who knows, at the moment? That's part of why I want to compile more information about them.
Well, you're going to have another chance in a few seconds.
Morganas are like leopards in a way, always taking us by surprise.
@BATTLE
What are you working on?
I'm trying to weave a traditional rug.
That sounds good. We could use some new carpeting around here.
The tricky part is figuring out how to put the different threads together so the colors blend just right.
It sounds pretty difficult.
It is. I'm trying to balance a lot of different things at once while keeping my eye on the larger picture I want at the end.
You know, that kind of sounds like the challenges we face in planning our operations.
I know. That's one of the reasons I like to try my hand at this. It's a good way to exercise the brain.
That's you, always keeping your mind on the battle even when we're out of it.
That's not quite true...
What do you mean?
Another reason why I was making this carpet was because I thought you might like it.
Wait, really?

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry I said that.
Thank you. I'll treasure it forever.
In that case, mind if I help?

Fields.DialogueText: That's all right. It's just something I'm trying to work on.
You're welcome. I hope you'll like it.
Sure! I can teach you some of the steps while I'm at it.
There! It's finished.
It's amazing. Thank you again, Del.
My pleasure, Captain.
*ALARM*
Good thing you finished this carpet. Got to look nice for the battle.
Be on your guard, Captain. If battles were won by the best dressed, this war would have been won inside of a fortnight.
@BATTLE
You doing all right, Delhi?
...Huh? Oh, yeah, I am! Whyever do you ask?
You kind of spaced out for a moment, and stared at the sky blankly. Did some of the projectiles damage you?
Nothing more than usual. They just brought back some bad memories.
What do you mean by that?
I had to deal with some bombs when I was helping refugees escape Franco. Since then, attacks from the sky have always made me a little nervous.
Because that's the one area you can't fight back against.
You sure know me, all right. Yes, that's exactly it. Sure, I can shoot down planes, but the bombs just fall and blow up, and there's nothing I can do about it.

Fields.MenuText: Not entirely. You can still help everyone recover and continue the fight afterward.
Don't focus on your faults too much. Just remember the skills you already have.
Hey, hang in there. I'm always here to back you up.

Fields.DialogueText: That's right. What really matters is moving forward after everything is through.
Good point. I may not be able to handle the sky, but I can take care of everything else just fine.
Thanks, Captain. I just wish I could do more to protect you.
Sorry... for being a burden.
You're never a bother, Delhi. So don't say that. That's an order!
Understood, Captain. Thank you...
Anyway, don't give up. We've got you covered for the next run.
Good. Now it's time to counterattack. Charge!
@BATTLE
You already do. So let me do my part in turn, all right?
That's a nice postcard, Delhi.
Brings back memories. This one was from when we visited Pearl Harbor.
That's neat. What did you think of it?
Well, to tell you the truth, I was more curious about the local fauna and volcanoes. But they had a pretty nice base out there. I hope they're doing fine now.
Why wouldn't they?
Well, with this crazy war, who knows what's safe anymore? Plus, I'm not sure how they'd do in an actual attack.
You worry about a lot of things, don't you?
With all my responsibilities and interests, I have a lot to protect. That's why I try not to get too attached to others.

Fields.MenuText: You have to have faith in your friends that they can take care of themselves, just as I, and they, believe in you.
Whatever comes, never regret the bonds you have made.
I'm sure they're doing well. Maybe we can visit them sometime?

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. It's demeaning to doubt them. I guess I have to put more faith in everyone, like how I believe in you.
I won't. Everything ends in time, but we cannot let go of what has given us life and hope.
That would be great. We could have so much fun there, you and me.
Anyway, we should worry more about the Morganas around here. Who knows when...
Here they come!
And speak of the devil. They won't sink us, ever!
@BATTLE
I'm glad you do. We make a damn good team.
There! That should do it!
Whoa, that's a big totem pole!
Like it? I remembered how the one in the harbor at Victoria looked really cool.
It looks kind of different from the usual one, though.
That's because I decided to use Indian animals and monsters for the figures.
I see. That's a pretty unique blend of art.
All the better that someone finally combined them, then.
That's certainly your style.
Plus, I'm hoping that this can serve as a sort of "good luck" charm for us.
Do you think it will work?
We'll see. I have faith in it, and in our ability to ensure we have good fortune in battle.

Fields.MenuText: I'm just worried that it might become bad luck if it topples over.
If anything, it might be enough to intimidate our enemies.
I hope that you picked lucky symbols, then.

Fields.DialogueText: You don't have to worry about that. I made sure it has a steady base.
If our bravery didn't scare them off, nothing will. Even so, it may give us a bit of an edge we can exploit.
I sure did. Everything from nagas to elephants to gandharvas.
Think we should put some paint on it?
Perhaps. Though we should probably wait. Those Morganas over there will probably get the deck all wet before we repay them in turn.
@BATTLE
That's good. On the other hand, it's gonna be a pain to move...
I note that the elephant is the biggest. No surprise there.
Hey there, Del. How's the garden coming along?
Great! I just made a few new additions.
Oh? What did you plant now–
Wait, don't come this way!
Yeowch! Cacti in a garden?
They're perfectly safe as long as you stay on the path. Plus, they're pretty good to eat and drink, once you deal with the spines.
I suppose you're right. But what gave you the idea of using a cactus?
Mostly, I wanted to do something like the Arab Baths at Palma.
That another place you visited?
Yes, but unfortunately I didn't have much time to see the sights. Plenty of fireworks, though.
Not the kind you want to hang around for, though.
Yeah, so I thought that I could sort of recreate it here. I hope you're fine with it.

Fields.MenuText: They actually look rather pretty.
Why don't we see about making a pleasure visit up there when the war's done?
I think you should put up a sign to warn people.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, so you like the flowers? It just goes to prove my philosophy: a splash of colour goes a long way in a sea of gray.
I don't know. We might not get a warm welcome. Still, we can try.
Not a bad idea. I'll see about making one.
You know, I think you Belles are sort of like cacti: prickly without and sweet within.
A very astute observation. Thank you. I like to think you've done a superb job navigating my spines... useful though they may be.
If only these Morganas were as easily pruned. I think it's time to do some weeding...
@BATTLE
Delhi, are you– whoa. Is this a desert to go with the cacti?
Why, no. This is a beach. Can't you tell?
Thank you for the clarification. I'd still like to know why there's a beach in the middle of the deck.
I was thinking this could help the crew relax like the shore leave we had at the West Indies.
That's a very kind idea, but I'm a little worried about the sand messing up the deck.
Come now, the boards could use a little sanding.
You know what I meant. This can be fun, but it can also be troublesome.
I know, but I just thought this could be a way for the crew and me to come together and enjoy ourselves.

Fields.MenuText: I see that this means a lot to you, so you can keep working at it. But that means you're responsible for the upkeep.
Why don't we work together, and I can figure out a way to make this work?
Will this really work out as a beach, though? A beach is defined by its constant contact with water.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain. And don't worry, I won't let you down.
That sounds great! I could use a second opinion on some of my plans.
You forget how water tends to splash up here every now and then. It should be enough to keep the right dampness.
Come on, just lie down and relax.
All right. Huh. It's rather nice and comfy.
See? I told you this would be great for morale.
Yeah... hey, why do I feel something on my chest?
I just put a little sand on top, so you get the whole experience.
Very funny.
Uh, oh. The Morganas have come to wreck our sandcastles.
Then we'd better get a move on! But first, help me up?
@BATTLE
You have a point.
Delhi, where are you? Delhi?
Boo!
Aaaa! That started me!
Neat mask, no? I got this in New Zealand.
From one of the native tribes?
Yes, this is one made by the Maori.
That's a pretty cool souvenir.
Yes, but the ones I value the most are invisible. Knowledge, legends, history... things best passed down by word of mouth.
That's amazing. You sure know a lot about the world.
For all the use it is to anyone.
What do you mean?
I only have tiny scraps from all over. They make a good mix together, but nothing substantial for any specific place. And besides, it's not like my superiors care.

Fields.MenuText: But didn't you also say that everything counts in life? So even if your experiences are small, they're surely valuable beyond measure.
On the other hand, if you just focused on a single place, you wouldn't have room for all those other marvelous lands you have traveled to.
If they won't listen to you, keep trying until they finally pay attention.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right... Everything we've done, however little, has made some ripples on this endless expanse.
I never looked at it from that angle. That would be even worse than the problems I have now.
That's kind of hard for me. But I won't give up.
Anyway, if you're worried you didn't learn enough while you were there, you could ask them for more information.
What do you mean?
Well, friendships are always changing and growing. So why not send them a postcard or something to keep the connection alive?
Yes, that could work... and then... yes, I've got it! Thank you, Captain.
Glad I could help out. Prepare for a fight, though. It looks like masks don't work on the Morganas.
@BATTLE
Let's see... Durban's been to England, Gibraltar, Africa...
What are you working on there? Some sort of tally?
Kind of. Remember what I said about my dream for the Belles?
You mean how they can bring different countries together?
You remembered! Anyway, your talk about writing back to the places I visited got me thinking. Our connections don't make a difference unless we act on them.
So what do you have in mind?
For now, I'm making a chart with all the places we've been to. Then I'm going to encourage everyone to reach out, both to those places and to each other.
I see. And then they'll begin to care more about how the different lands interact with each other.
You've got it! I just hope that the girls will be open to my idea.

Fields.MenuText: Just speak from the heart. I know you'll be able to persuade them.
You won't know until you try. Might as well give it a shot.
Let's take this one step at a time. We'll make this all work in the end.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, I just need to find the courage to speak out.
Good point. If nothing's done, nothing will get done. In fact, things might get worse.
Right. I need to focus on this stage before I can worry about the next part.
Thanks for the advice.
Don't mention it. I'm really excited about your plan.
So am I. I hope it works.
Hey, I'll be here for you, no matter what happens.
Thanks.
Getting the Morganas to communicate properly, on the other hand, is another matter entirely.
@BATTLE
There! This should be my greatest concoction yet!
Mm... I can smell something good. What have you got for us today?
Mango curry and Worcestershire sauce, my own special combo.
Interesting. You have a gift for bringing together different cultural ideas.
Thanks! And the ingredients were all specially picked from the gardens.
Even better. Although, the mix looks kind of... unique.
That's the whole point. Would you like a taste?
All right, sure. I'll try some for you.
Great! I'm curious to see what you think of it. This is my first time creating this recipe.
So I'm the guinea pig? Oh, fine. Here I go.
Well? What did you think of it?

Fields.MenuText: Delicious!
It could use a little more seasoning, but it was pretty good.
Sorry, but it's not my kind of thing.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm glad you like it. Let me know when you want a second helping.
Thank you for being honest about it. To tell you the truth, I was wondering if I had the right balance or not. But now I know what to change.
That's all right. We all have our own preferences. What makes me happy is that you were willing to try it.
Next up, I think that I will make shrimp skewers in pudding. Think that will work out?
We'll have to see. For now, we have some other fish to fry.
I see what you mean. Fortunately, I'm always ready to dig in.
@BATTLE
Thanks!
Ugh, this pile never seems to get lower. Join the navy, they said. See the world, they said. Nobody mentioned the bureaucratic end of things.
Say, Captain, are you up for some scuba diving? It's not the same as Samara, but it looks like there's plenty to see down below.
Could we wait a little bit, please? I'm kind of busy with this paperwork, and I'd need to get changed anyway.
Come on, just for a little while? It will be fun!
I'm sure that some of your other friends would love to join you.
I know, but... I wanted to do this with you.
With me?
Just the two of us, down beneath the waves.
Delhi...
I'm sorry about bothering you with this. It's great that you put up with all of my antics. But, even if it means I neglect some of my other bonds, I want to have time with you.

Fields.MenuText: I just thought you'd want someone else. I'll probably get in the way.
Actually, why not? It sounds like fun.
Sorry for being a spoilsport. I'd love to have some quality time with you.

Fields.DialogueText: I can work around that. We're a team, after all, so we balance each other out.
Thanks. This will be awesome.
Really? Great!
Well, what are we waiting for?
Hey, hold on– wah!
Nice splash, Captain! I wish I could do that.
Thanks. But come on in, the water's great!
Actually, you might want to get back up here.
Nuts. Of all the times for them to show up.
Sorry I got you wet, Captain.
Don't worry. We can take another dive once we're through here.
@BATTLE
That's an interesting pot you've made there, Delhi.
Thanks. I based the design off the traditions of the Patamona of Guyana.
That's pretty neat. I like the snake design.
Yes, that's my favorite part as well. It highlights the diversity of life in the rainforest.
I take it there's a lot of snakes.
And birds, and lizards, and fish, and frogs, and flowers. There are all sorts of things out in the Amazon.
Cool. What's the vase's purpose for, out of curiosity?
... It's a funeral urn.
Oh. Isn't it kind of bad luck to have that on board?
Well, it is kind of fitting, given how their home is so rapidly disappearing.
Yeah, it's easy to lose sight of all the other battles humanity is fighting. Especially lately.
Sometimes I wonder... who are we fighting for? The world, or just a few who claim to represent its entirety?

Fields.MenuText: If it's the latter, let's do our best to make it the former.
That depends on our choices, and how we decide to proceed.
Perhaps we aren't helping everyone, but at least we're making a difference for someone out there.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. No use whining about it when we can open people's eyes to the larger world.
I know. I just sometimes doubt. Fortunately, I always get back on my feet.
Yes, we are. Every breath we take leaves its mark on the world, so let's make our work count, all right?
Feel better now?
Yeah, thanks.
You still didn't answer me, though. What does the urn mean to you?
To symbolize how we are conducting funerals and burials for the Morganas.
That's true, I suppose. Then we had best get on with the next ceremony. Shall we?
@BATTLE
That's what I lo... like most about you.
Got it!
Delhi, are you in here?
Why, yes. Did you wish to speak with me about something?
I just had a little surprise for you. Here!
It's...
A tea bowl. I made it myself. It's a Japanese style, so I don't know if you'll like it, but...
It's gorgeous. Thank you! But, how will I repay you for this?
You don't need to do anything, Delhi. I'm just happy that you like it.
You don't understand. You didn't need to help me in this manner. I could have handled it myself.
You don't like it?
It's not that! I... just worry that I'll get weighed down if I become too dependent on anyone.

Fields.MenuText: Bonds aren't straightforward, Delhi. They might not be perfect, but in a way that's what makes them engaging.
You will never become like that, Delhi. Sure, there are things I'm better at, but you're a brave, kind huntress. Remember that.
Think of this not as an obligation on you, but rather a thanks for getting me interested in tea.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. Everything in life is imperfect yet beautiful in its own way. I guess that same applies for our partnership.
I will, thank you.
Oh? You're welcome, then. I'm glad you found you like the drink.
Anyway, want to share some tea now?
How about we wait until we deal with these incoming enemies?
Good idea. It's the perfect way to celebrate our victory.
Yes, but don't count your cows until we deal with the tigers.
@BATTLE
How's that for my swordplay, Del? Not bad, huh?
All right, Captain. You've been doing very well with the training. But now it's time to work on your use of the shield.
All right. But we've already been using training shields.
I mean something more permanent. Here, I want you to have this.
Whoa. You want me to use this?
And keep it. It is one of a kind. I had to forge it myself.
... Thank you. I'm kind of surprised, though. It looks more Grecian than Indian.
Well, my class is Danae, after all. I thought this would make a nice present for you. Is it all right?
It's perfect. Huh, is that the Medusa head? I take it that this is based off Perseus's shield.
Yes. He was the son of Danae, and went on to become a great hero. I felt that it was only fitting that you carry on his legacy.

Fields.MenuText: In that case, maybe I should make a special shield for you.
Like mother to son, huh?
I'll do my best to make you proud, teacher.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? I was thinking of making it on my own, but... that sounds wonderful.
... In a way, sort of. Loveable fool.
I know you will, every day, just as I do my best for you likewise.
In that case, charge!
Heh, you're learning fast. But I'm not going to make it easy for you.
Never expected otherwise. We bring out our strengths, don't we?
We sure do. Let's use that same courage against the Morganas.
@BATTLE
What do you mean?
... It's nothing, really.
General quarters, everyone! If it floats, it can certainly sink!
@BATTLE
Glad that's finally over.
But we made it, right?
Most of us. But no matter what, someone, whether here or elsewhere, is falling. And the darkness continues to fall. Sometimes I wonder if the fates are toying with us.
Heroes from Achilles to Arjuna have pondered that same question. But in the end, it comes down to faith.
And what do you believe in, Del? What makes you think that we can find peace?
"Chosen, not destroyed."
Pardon?
That is my ship's motto. For a long time, I wondered what my makers meant by that. But now I have an answer.
And what is your conclusion?
That the destinies that guide us ultimately love us all. We have all been chosen for life. And even if we sink, we will never truly be destroyed. Nothing will, as long as we love.

Fields.MenuText: It takes deep courage to have faith that you will live on even as you die.
Yes, love is what gives us hope in life, isn't it?
I'm not sure I can have my full trust in fate saving us.

Fields.DialogueText: I know, and I wonder if I'll stay chipper when I go down. But hey, nothing's ever easy, is it?
One day, I know we'll each find love and destiny.
That's why I said destinies. The fates don't expect us to get a free ride the whole way. We have to make it happen for things to move forward.
Anyway, just look on the bright side right now, all right? A sad captain makes me feel sad, too.
Then I'll let your spirit infect me. Because a happy Delhi makes me happy as well.
You're so funny, Captain.
Thanks. So why don't we check out the victory party?
I can't wait!
... Yeah.
Say, Captain, do you think you could help me for a bit, please?
Sure. What are you working on?
I'm writing a book.
About?
Well, I'm going to expand it in time, but for now it's about me.
I see. This has to do with your cross-cultural vision, doesn't it?
It does. I'm... going to publish my own story. About my journeys and my heritage.
Whoa. You're really going to do that, huh? Are you all right, knowing what might happen?
I am. It's been tough to get this far, but... I'm ready, no matter what happens.
Great. I know this means a lot to you, so I'm happy that you are pursuing your dream.
Thanks. Captain...
Yes?
I'm not sure what will happen once this is published, but I know I can make it through if I have you there. So promise me you'll be here for me.

Fields.MenuText: I already made that promise a while back, when you first told me what you had in mind.
To seal the promise, how about I include my own chapter in the compilation?
I can't promise that I'll be there forever, given the war, but I will help you for as long as I can.

Fields.DialogueText: You did? That makes me really happy, for some reason.
That sounds perfect. I could use your extra insights on things.
That's all I can ask of you. Let's make the most of the time we have left.
But anyway, you never did say what you needed my help with for the book.
Oh, you're right! It wasn't much. I was just having a little trouble deciding how to lead into the discussion.
Huh. Well, I can help you come up with something – after we sink this fleet.
Nothing like a good battle to get the mind thinking.
@BATTLE
Mmm, do I smell something tasty!
You sure do! I'm really excited about the unique delicacy.
Mind if I have a look? I'm curious to see what scrumptious morsel we'll be having ne...
Something wrong?
You need to clean out the bowl, Delhi! There's a bunch of bugs crawling around in it!
There's no need to worry about that. They're the main course.
We're having bugs for dinner?
It's a worldwide phenomenon. You can find examples everywhere from Australia to South America. People just need to be more open to the idea.
Are you sure this is safe?
Of course! In fact, the protein will be good for you.

Fields.MenuText: I'm just worried about where the insects have been. Is this sanitary?
I can't promise I'll like it, but I'll try it.
All right. I trust you, Del, so I'll put my faith in your food.

Fields.DialogueText: That's why I'm heating them up right now. They should be perfectly fine in a few minutes.
Thanks. I hope you'll enjoy them.
That's very sweet of you, Captain. I won't let you down.
So, it's ready now?
It is! Go on, have a bite!
Well, all right. ... Huh. It kind of tastes like potato chips.
Really? I'd think it would be more like chicken, since they're both healthy.
In any case, it's pretty good. Let's get everybody together.
We'll have to hold off on that. The Morganas are really swarming today.
Hopefully we can squash them before they get too pesky.
@BATTLE
Captain, do you have time for a short lesson?
I always have time for you. But didn't we do some exercises just a little earlier?
Actually, I wanted to teach you how to sew properly.
Really? I hope that it isn't too much trouble to you.
It isn't. I think that this way, you will know how to fix up your own clothes when they get damaged in battle.
I'm sorry. I didn't realize that I was being a burden on you. I really appreciated your help fixing them every now and then.
It's not that I don't enjoy helping you. I just think that you should know how to do it on your own.
So I don't have to depend on you.
That's right. I know that it's good for us to still help each other out, but I want you to be able to stand on your own. After all, who knows how long I'll be here to protect you?

Fields.MenuText: I don't want to think about that happening, but you're right. I'll make sure I can live as long as I can. That's what you would want from me.
How about I learn to patch up your clothes? Then we'll be both doing each other a favor.
Let's hope that such a day does not come. I don't know what I would do without you.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. I want you to be able to be happy, no matter what happens.
That could work. It might not be the way I usually do it, but it could be fun to try it out.
I feel the same way. But we need to be strong and live, no matter what. That is what makes our sacrifices worth all the while.
Then let's get started. Actually, hold off. I see a Morgana.
Well, it will make a nice activity to relax after we're through with them.
Quite right. Now then, time to needle them until they sink.
@BATTLE
Mind if I dry up in here for a little while?
Go right ahead. Another rainy day, huh?
Indeed. It's raining cats and dogs out there, and it looks like it might shift to wolves and tigers soon enough.
Sigh... That kind of weather seems to provoke a somber atmosphere.
It will let up. You'll see.
But the bigger storm, the one hunting us, won't. I don't know if it will ever will.
You know, this reminds of an old story. There was a terrible flood, but the heavens forewarned a man, and he saved his people and all life.
The tale of Noah, right?
Actually, I meant the Indian one. You can find similar narratives all around the world. I think that's because, deep in our past, there was a terrible calamity in the oceans.
I see. So where are you going with this?
I wonder sometimes if the Morganas are the harbingers for a new great flood, one that will change the world.
That would be awful, if it's anything like the last one.
Actually, I take comfort in the flood's story.
Pardon?
When I look back at those stories, I see hope; a promise that, no matter what happens, life will endure and shed light in the darkness.

Fields.MenuText: Let's do our best to protect as many people as we can, then.
We'll make it through the storms, I know it.
I guess there's always a rainbow at the end of every trial.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. We may be facing insurmountable odds, but we can still make a difference and help life continue.
I know it as well. Our l... long-held bond will keep us together.
And every ending is a beginning. Life endlessly cycles, so we should always stay hopeful.
*ALARM*
Well, the storm's let up, but the true maelstrom has only begun. Time to get to work.
I'm with you all the way, always.
@BATTLE
Take heart, everyone! The feast I have planned will be all the sweeter for our victory!
@BATTLE
Hey, what's up? Everyone's getting ready for the celebration, if you're interested.
Actually, could we stay here for a little while?
Sure. It sure feels peaceful now that the battle is over.
We did really good out there today, working together.
We always do. That's because we want to understand each other.
And I want to learn more. There's... something I want to ask.
What is it? Something with your plans on the book?
No, I... you've helped me a lot.
I've been more than happy to help you learn to become friends with people.
The thing is, I think I value one bond more than the others.

Fields.MenuText: What do you mean?

Fields.DialogueText: The way we flow together in combat, the way you make me laugh during peacetime, it's made me feel warm inside.
That... sounds like love.
I have reached the same hypothesis.
Well, should we not test it? Such as with a date?
That sounds great! But first, let's get to the party, you and me. Our friends are waiting for us.
Yes. All of our connections – family, friends, loves – are all precious.
And we'll continue to make more, together.

Fields.MenuText: Funny. I was thinking that myself. I couldn't imagine anyone by my side... on the battlefield or off.

Fields.DialogueText: I've found... that I feel quite similarly.

Fields.MenuText: That doesn't sound like a problem to me.

Fields.DialogueText: Quite the opposite. It's a really... comfortable feeling. Whether we're fighting or learning about the world, I'm happy to be doing it with you.
